text: , also romanized as Suchō or Akamitori, was a which lsated only a few monthsfrom June through September 686.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Shuchō" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 889. The reigning monarchs were Nussbaum, "Temmu Tennō," p. 957. and .Nussbaum, "Jitō Tennō," p. 426; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 58-59. ==History== * In 686, was created by Emperor Temmu, but the nengō survived for only a few months after Temmu's death. The era ended when Empress Jitō was confirmed as Temmu's successor. ===Timeline=== The system of Japanese era names was not the same as Imperial reign dates. ==Events of the Shuchō era== * 686 (Shuchō 1, 9th day of the 9th month): Emperor Temmu died.Titsingh, p. 59; Imperial Household Agency (Kunaichō), 天武天皇 (40); retrieved 2012-5-22. * 686 (Shuchō 1): Ōtsu no Ōji, also known as Ōtsu no shinnō, tried and failed to make himself emperor after Temmu's death.Nussbaum, "Ōtsu no Ōji," p. 766; Titsingh, p. 59-60. * 686: The succession (senso) was received by Mommu's widow. Soon after, Empress Jitō's role as monarch was confirmed in ceremonies (sokui).Titsingh, p. 59; Varley, pp. 44, 137–138; a distinct act of senso is unrecognized prior to Emperor Tenji; and all sovereigns except Jitō, Yōzei, Go-Toba, and Fishimi have senso and sokui in the same year until the reign of Emperor Go-Murakami. Compare Kunaichō, Ceremony of Accession (Sokui-no-Rei); retrieved 2012-6-13. ==Related pages== * Asuka period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Shuchō 1st Gregorian 686 Preceded by: ---- Era or nengō: Shuchō Succeeded by: ---- Preceded by: Kōbun period 672 Imperial reign: Temmu period 673–686 Succeeded by: Jitō period 686–697 Category:Japanese eras Category:686 Category:7th century in Japan
title: Shuchō
